awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Validating and Scaling a Financial and Entrepreneurial Aptitude Assessment
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is the development of an intelligent and evolving tool that provides a framework to teach financial literacy skills to children. The literacy lessons are implemented at the child’s pace and stage of development. The product seeks to provide a family finance and entrepreneurism platform that combines real money, peer performance feedback, and artificial intelligence (AI)-driven education to teach youth how to responsibly use money and build businesses. By utilizing AI, the project will curate educational content into an immersive digital learning experience that is tailored to the individual regardless of wealth, demographics, or geographic location. Through this innovation, youth may be better positioned for success as they transition to financial independence. This project may also allow academia and industry to work together to validate an individual's financial preparedness and independence.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project focusses on designing the principles and mechanics of a user performance feedback mechanism that promotes financial wellness. Financial literacy is important at every stage of life. The Phase I of this project is to develop a performance mechanism and uses deep AI techniques to baseline the goals for data collection and logical data organization, as well as to determine performance measurements and individual learner groupings. These metrics include static data, dynamic data, logical organization of data, calculation methods, and scoring principles. Once optimized, the outcome of the project may encourage individuals to achieve financial stability and success.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report Project Title: Enhancing Financial Literacy with the Financial Education Assessment Tool (FEAT) Score

Principal Investigator (PI): James Haluszczak

Start Date: September 1, 2022

End Date: August 31, 2023

Project Goals:

In Phase I, our primary focus was to lay the foundation for an innovative feature within our NuMoola app – the Financial Education Assessment Tool (FEAT) Score. This feature, now known as the Financial Education Assessment Tool Score based on customer feedback, aimed to enrich our app's functionality by introducing a performance scoring mechanism. Our overarching goal was to enhance the financial literacy of young individuals and empower them to make informed financial decisions.

Project Outcomes and Impact:

Intellectual Merit: Our project has made significant intellectual contributions to the field of financial education and technology. We successfully designed and conceptualized the FEAT Score, which represents a novel approach to assessing financial literacy among young users. Our team meticulously defined data collection requirements, crafted data collection methods, established an entry-level rules engine, and initiated the formulation of calculation and comparison techniques. These efforts have not only laid the groundwork for a valuable tool but also advanced the understanding of how technology can be leveraged to promote financial literacy.

Our engagement with 30 beta customers further enriched our intellectual merit. Their feedback highlighted the importance of real-time, in-app performance feedback as a powerful educational tool. This insight has broad implications for the design of effective educational technology, demonstrating the value of immediate feedback in enhancing learning outcomes.

Broader Impacts:

The broader impacts of our project extend beyond intellectual contributions. We recognize the critical importance of financial literacy in today's society, and our work directly addresses this pressing need. By developing the FEAT Score and incorporating it into the NuMoola app, we aim to empower young individuals with the knowledge and tools they need to navigate the complex world of personal finance.

Our engagement with beta customers highlighted the potential for the FEAT Score to positively impact financial education. The enthusiasm expressed by users, particularly in response to peer performance comparisons, underscores the broader societal impact of our work. By instilling financial literacy and responsible financial decision-making in young individuals, we contribute to their long-term financial well-being and overall financial health.

Our commitment to improving financial literacy remains steadfast, and the success of Phase I positions us well to continue advancing our mission in subsequent phases of this project.

Conclusion:

In conclusion, Phase I of our project has made significant contributions to both the intellectual merit and broader impacts of financial education and technology. We have successfully designed the principles of the Financial Education Assessment Tool (FEAT) Score, advanced the understanding of technology's role in financial literacy, and garnered valuable insights from beta customers.

Our mission to enhance financial literacy and empower young individuals to make informed financial decisions aligns with the broader societal goal of improving financial well-being. We look forward to the continued support of the NSF and the opportunity to make a meaningful impact on financial education for the next generation. Our journey to improve financial literacy is ongoing, and we are committed to bringing this important tool to young users who are eager to build a secure financial future.

 


Last Modified: 09/22/2023
Modified by: James Haluszczak
